media.description:
Let's etch the glass in the bottom of this mug.
It's frosty now, it needs to come to room temperature.
media.title: 20151212_111026.jpg

media.description:
We need to wash it to make sure the mask adheres properly and the etchant can work on the surface of the glass.
I use Dawn, it cuts grease, cleans, and is gentle on my delicate hands.
media.title: 20151212_111052.jpg

media.description: After washing and drying it is still damp and chilly, so I decided to warm it up here while I did the computer stuff.
media.title: 20151212_111152.jpg

media.description: Eagle Lake is a nice font
media.title: 20151212_112204.jpg

media.description:
Silhouette studio is the software I need to use Bobs cutter.  
Both the cutter and the free software are very good.
media.title: 20151212_112209.jpg

media.description: Marked the center line and center on the bottom of the outside of the mug with dry erase marker for alignment later.
media.title: 20151212_113135.jpg

media.description: This is what it looks like from inside the mug.
media.title: 20151212_113234.jpg

media.description: Laying out the design in Silhouette Studio
media.title: 20151212_113255.jpg

media.description:
Some test cuts.
I'm using blue painters tape as the etch mask.  The paper/vinyl cutter will cut the pattern out.
I don't have the feed sheet for the cutter so I had to iterate on the settings a little bit; the best settings were to use adhesive sticker backing from Star Castle 2600 shipping labels taped to a sheet of card stock and print with the "white paper labels" stock options.
media.title: 20151212_121908.jpg

media.description: The pattern is cut but you can't see it.  The red crossed lines should line up with the center of the bottom of the mug.  I'm using the Exacto knife to cut the pattern out to transfer it before "weeding".
media.title: 20151212_123203.jpg

media.description: The pattern had to be carefully transferred into the cup using two long pairs of tweezers.  Note the extra piece of tape over the "a" in "Jack", that is to keep the center of the "a" intact and aligned while transferring.
media.title: 20151212_123503.jpg

media.description: Using a pointed probe and tweezers to "weed" the mask (remove the part where the acid will go).
media.title: 20151212_123758.jpg

media.description:
Using some nonstick silicone adhesive sticker backing and a rounded tool to burnish the mask.  
Applying a lot of pressure around the edges of the pattern ensures good adhesion.  
Gaps will allow the acid to be drawn under the mask by capillary action.
media.title: 20151212_124056.jpg

media.description:
Rounded end of the tool, this one being a pocket screwdriver from Xylotex, the makers of the motors on my CNC machine.  
It was the only smooth rounded pen end I could find that didn't have a rough injection molding bit on it.
media.title: 20151212_124106.jpg

media.description:
I've applied tape all over the inside of the mug for a couple of reasons.
First: To prevent mistakes if I'm sloppy with the acid.
Second: Remember, the only way to get the acid out when it is done is to rinse it out, the tape ensures that if any makes contact with the glass it will be seriously diluted by then.
media.title: 20151212_124539.jpg

media.description:
Checking the adhesion and alignment from the bottom of the mug.
Looks good!
media.title: 20151212_124548.jpg

media.description:
Time to start etching.
Suggestion to the Armour Etch company:  Put the directions on the bottle.  
All of the fine print is what to do in case it touches your skin, eyes, mouth...  and it's all pretty bad.
I looked it up, it said to apply a thick coat and leave it on for one minute.  
Since I really want to create a rough surface for beer bubbles to nucleate on, I left it on for over two minutes.
media.title: 20151212_131032.jpg

media.description: The etching cream is applied.
media.title: 20151212_131926.jpg

media.description: Does not look like there was any leakage under the mask.
media.title: 20151212_132201.jpg

media.description: It's always hard to tell how well the etch went when the glass is wet, and it is harder with the mask still on, but this is rinsed and it looks really good!
media.title: 20151212_132313.jpg

media.description:
Washed and dried with a paper towel.
It looks great!
The etch looks a little weak towards the center in some pictures but that is because it hadn't air dried fully when I took the pictures.
media.title: 20151212_132606.jpg

media.description: You know, the inside of a glass mug is really hard to take good pictures of.
media.title: 20151212_132824.jpg

media.description: This is what the rest of us will see from the outside as Jack enjoys his beer.
media.title: 20151212_132841.jpg

media.description: Jack enjoying his new mug
media.title: 20151219_161551.jpg

media.description: Jack enjoying his new mug
media.title: 20151219_161557.jpg
